text: the innate immune response is a general
response that your immune system has
against foreign invaders and there are
special cells involved in the process in
this video we're going to dig into those
cells and the roles they play so let's
do it
[Music]
hey this is leslie samuel here from
interactive biology tv where we're
making biology fun and we're talking
about the cells of the innate immune
response but first a quick review
something foreign enters your body your
immune system doesn't like that it wants
to get rid of that invader whether it's
a bacteria virus or some other pathogen
there's a quick initial response that
doesn't care what specific invader it is
it's a non-specific response and by
non-specific here's what we mean if it's
inside and it doesn't belong to you we
want it gone it's not you so bye bye and
then there's a slower response that does
care what the specific antigen is in
fact its response is specifically
tailored to specific pathogens man
that's a whole lot of specific but for
more info on this idea of non-specific
versus specific see my video on the
introduction to the immune system i'll
also make another video pretty soon
comparing the two in more depth so make
sure you're subscribed for when that
comes out
in this video we're looking at that
quick initial response that's more
general in nature something's bad inside
and we want to get rid of whatever it is
and there are a number of cells that are
involved in this process and we'll look
at them right now the first category of
cells is called a phagocyte these are
cells that have the ability to engulf
foreign particles the word phagocyte
literally means eating cell they'll eat
the potentially harmful substance take
it inside themselves with the goal of
destroying it now there are two main
phagocytes the macrophages and the
neutrophils macrophages are phagocytes
that have an irregular shape and what's
cool about these macrophages is that
they can leave the circulatory system by
squeezing through the walls of the
capillaries because they can do this
they can roam through the tissues and
when they encounter a pathogen they do
what they do they will basically eat up
that pathogen using a process called
phagocytosis it's like pac-man eating
those dots in the game you know what i
mean now depending on where you find
these macrophages in the body you might
see them called by different names if
they're in the lungs they're called
alveolar macrophages if they're in the
liver they're called kapha cells and if
they're in the connective tissue they're
called histiocytes don't let all the
names confuse you they're all basically
macrophages i just want you to know
about these names just in case you see
them in a textbook you know what it's
talking about macrophages also have
another function they can release these
signaling molecules known as cytokines
and those cytokines will attract other
immune cells to the area pictures of
macrophages kind of like security guards
in the mall someone's trying to cause
damage in a mall or trying to steal
something they catch the person and they
try to deal with them and they can also
use their little walkie-talkies to call
other guards and even the police if
necessary that's like the macrophages
first doing what they do phagocytosis
and then sending out cytokines to bring
in the reinforcements okay the next type
of phagocyte that's part of the innate
immune response is the neutrophil these
are granulocytes meaning they have
granules inside their cytoplasm they're
basically little containers or vesicles
that have stuff inside them in the case
of the neutrophils they have things like
histamines and other substances
neutrophils are very good at dealing
with things like bacteria and fungi you
can think of these as the police
officers that are called in by the
signals from the security guards they
have receptors on their surfaces that
will detect the cytokines and other
substances that are released by
different cells and they'll respond by
coming into the area eating stuff up
releasing histamines to trigger
inflammation and other substances like
antimicrobials to fight against bacteria
then there are monocytes monocytes are
interesting cells they aren't fully
developed in fact they are precursor
cells that have the ability to
differentiate and become either a
macrophage or a dendritic cell and we'll
talk about dendritic cells a little
later the idea here is that they're
circulating in the blood and depending
on the signals they receive when there's
some kind of pathogen they can become
what they need to become so that they
can best help the situation and try to
get rid of that potentially harmful
substance i don't know about you but i
think that's pretty cool next we have
the mast cells you can find these in
connective tissue and also in mucous
membranes now these are going to play a
very important role when there's a cut
it helps with the healing process and
with protection against pathogens let's
say you get a cut mast cells in that
area are going to get activated and
they'll release cytokines and other
substances that cause inflammation
things like histamine anytime you hear
histamine i want you to think
inflammation the idea is we're trying to
get more blood to the area so that we
can bring in more of the recruits get
more of those immune system cells here
to fight off infection and to promote
healing which is a good thing okay now
let's get to the eusinophils these cells
are involved in fighting against
parasites and bacteria but they're also
active when dealing with allergic
reactions they are also granulocytes so
that means that they have substances in
their granules and in this case they are
toxic to both bacteria and parasites now
here's the issue when eosinophils
release their granules into the tissues
to fight against a parasite or something
else those chemicals can also cause
damage to our own tissues so the process
of releasing granules needs to be
regulated next we have basophils once
again a granulocyte you know what that
means they have granules and the
granules have stuff inside of them in
this case we're also dealing with
histamine which causes inflammation
especially when we're dealing with
allergic reactions okay we have two more
cells to cover the next one is the
natural killer cells or nk cells these
cells are different in that they don't
directly attack the pathogen instead
they detect when a cell has been
infected by a pathogen and trigger a
process called apoptosis which basically
means cellular death they have granules
inside that release substances like
perforins and granzymes the perforins
will basically perforate the cell wall
making holes throughout the membrane and
the granzymes are gonna enter the cell
to trigger apoptosis killing the cell
this works very well when a cell has
been infected like with a virus one more
cell the dendritic cell i mentioned this
one earlier when i show that they can
develop from monocytes these cells are
also called antigen presenting cells
they're present in tissues that are in
direct contact with the external
environment places like the skin the
lining of the nose and the lungs the
stomach and the intestines since they're
exposed to the external environment they
often identify pathogens and present
them to the rest of the immune system
triggering a non-specific inflammatory
response it's kind of like they take up
the bad stuff and then present it all to
the other cells saying hey this is bad
stuff kill it but they'll also present
them to b and t cells to trigger a
specific immune response and because of
this they're often seen as a bridge
between the innate and the adaptive
immune responses so those are the cells
that are involved in innate immunity you
know i don't mention this enough this is
a lot of info unfortunately we take
notes of all this stuff and we put it on
our blog so that you can always review
them at your own leisure i'll link to
the post for this episode in the
description below now in the next video
we're going to dig into adaptive
immunity a little bit more specifically
we're going to start by looking at the t
cells and how they function but that's
